Text: The earth is the LORD’s, and everything in it, the world, and all who live in it.
Context: This verse establishes God‘s sovereignty over all creation.

Text: For He has founded it upon the seas and established it upon the rivers.
Context: The psalmist explains God’s act of creation, implying His legitimate ownership over the earth.

Text: Who may ascend the mountain of the LORD? Who may stand in His holy place?
Context: The verse poses rhetorical questions regarding the qualifications for approaching God‘s holy presence.

Text: He who has clean hands and a pure heart, who does not lift up his soul to an idol or swear by what is false.
Context: This verse answers the previous, stating the moral and spiritual purity required to approach God.

Text: He will receive blessing from the LORD and vindication from the God of his salvation.
Context: Assures that those who are righteous will be blessed and justified by God.

Text: Such is the generation of those who seek Him, who seek Your face, O God of Jacob.
column7: Refers to the collective identity of those who earnestly seek a relationship with God.

Text: Lift up your heads, O gates! Be lifted up, O ancient doors, that the King of glory may enter in!
Context: Calls for the gates of the city (or metaphorical gates) to open for the triumphant entry of God.

Text: Who is this King of glory? The LORD strong and mighty, the LORD mighty in battle.
Context: Asks rhetorically to highlight attributes of the LORD as a mighty warrior.

Text: Lift up your heads, O gates! Lift them up, O ancient doors, that the King of glory may come in!
Context: Repeats the call for the gates to open, emphasizing anticipation of God’s entry.

Text: Who is He, this King of glory? The LORD of hosts, He is the King of glory. Selah
Context: Answers the rhetorical question posed in verse 8, proclaiming the LORD‘s supreme glory and authority.
